file_content.text: Better get moving--you hang around the shop for too long, people will get suspicious.
Hey! Sounds like things went pretty well with the station chief. I'm glad to hear it--you deserve a little praise.
You kept the bloodshed to a minimum. And I'm grateful, you know?
Keeping the body count low seemed the best solution, under the circumstances.
This job is about efficiency.
Yeah, well--it was something I could never pull off. So nice work.
I followed my conscience.
I don't know what you're talking about.
No idea.
Of course you don't. That's why you're a better agent than I'll ever be. Well... one reason.
I'm not sure what I'll be doing now that Chemish and Gray Star are out of the picture. Or even what I want to be doing.
And I guess you're leaving Balmorra? It's too bad--would've been nice to spend some time together outside of work.
That's the business we're in. And you have no idea what I'm really like, Sanju.
You don't want to get close.
Yeah. Okay. Maybe not.
If you want to celebrate, I don't have to leave the planet quite yet.
We've got time now.
I'm up for it if you are. A few drinks, maybe? And if the station chief asks where we went, well--I'll just say you swore me to secrecy....
All right. I'll let you get back to work. And who knows? Maybe we'll run into each other again, someday.
I could use another partner. You could always tag along--learn to pilot a ship, use a blaster properly....
Why not come with me?
Be well, Sanju.
Another time--it's been fun.
Right, maybe.
You know, it has been, hasn't it?
I don't need you drooling all over me, Sanju.
Don't flatter yourself.
Hey, all right--can't blame me for trying.
Guess you don't have that problem--you must be ready to leave Balmorra, get on to your next assignment.
That's what a Cipher does. Not much choice in the matter.
All part of the job.
So I hear.
I could use another pair of hands. You could join my team.
Want to tag along?
Heh. I appreciate the offer, but... Balmorra's my home. Besides, I don't think I could keep up.
Besides, I get itchy if I'm not shooting anyone.
More violence awaits.
You know, you say that, but I'm not sure I believe it. Not that I'm going to test you.
Watch yourself out there. I hear it's a nasty galaxy, and if the Empire's going to run the place, well... we need folks like you.
I'd love to chat, but you should probably talk to the station chief first. Maybe after?
Hey! I don't have long, but please tell me you didn't deliver the package to the Republic base yet.
What's going on, Sanju?
Why?
I haven't delivered the package yet.
Okay.
Then I have good news.
If you're interrupting me, you'd better have some damn important information.
This had better be good.
It's important. Let me explain.
That package you're carrying is for Gray Star--the terror cell leader.
Gray Star's the man inside the Republic base. Chemish wants to extract him, and you've been sent to help.
What's Gray Star doing in the Republic base?
That's strange.
You're sure?
That information you got from the training camp turned out to be real handy.
If you're right, then Gray Star is mine.
We've found the target.
That's how it looks.
As best I can tell, Gray Star has been secretly managing and supplying the terror cell while pretending to be a loyal Republic officer.
It was the perfect cover--until the Republic started to suspect. Now Gray Star needs to escape before he's caught.
He's not going anywhere. I can promise that.
I don't think so.
Why does the Republic care?
Why?
The terrorists aren't going to let the Republic take Balmorra back. The Empire's their main enemy, but they don't think the Republic's much better.
Republic soldiers, the terrorist leader and anyone else in there--they're dead.
So I'll just kill everyone.
Well, maybe--but there's something else.
Your package contains instructions and maps leading to a safe house. But... we could change those instructions. Send Gray Star into a trap.
Once we have Gray Star, we could make him give up his security protocols. We could send out orders to the cell using his name.
In that case, the Empire would have the whole cell as a puppet.
We'd control the terrorists?
That's the idea.
Awfully risky.
I don't know why we'd bother.
Seems pointless.
Consider the benefits.
I know how Chemish and her people think. If we capture Gray Star and learn what he knows, I can forge convincing orders.
Chief Renald's been looking for a way to turn the terrorists against the Republic for ages. We can make it work.
You're trickier than I thought, Sanju.
Very clever thinking.
How?
I'm here to destroy the terror cell, not subvert it.
That's not my mission.
If you say so. Me? I'd rather see Chemish and her people under Imperial control than running around without a leader.
I'm sending you rendezvous coordinates. If you want to do this thing, tell Gray Star to meet me there--I'll arrange the rest.
If you don't send him my way, well... I guess you'll have to kill him.
You have anything else for me?
Is that all?
I don't think it'll come to killing Gray Star.
Murder won't be necessary.
This was never going to end without Gray Star's death.
Killing was always my plan.
Good luck, then.
I don't know if I'll see you again. Depending on what happens with Gray Star, I may have to go into hiding for a while.
But... it's been an honor working with you. Sanju out.
I'm so sorry. I don't know what happened--Chemish just snapped! Are you okay?
Looks like she suspected something after all.
We underestimated Chemish.
No kidding. I'm sorry--I'll take the blame if Renald needs an explanation. For now, let's salvage what we can.
Fine.
That's good. That's--yeah, that's good. Now we just need to figure out what to do next.
I'm fine, you're fine--but the operation is ruined.
The mission is a shambles.
Don't give up hope yet.
This isn't the way I wanted to play it, but with Chemish dead, we've got access to her datapads and her holocommunicator.
Between the information on her systems and the data you got from the training outpost, maybe we can find Gray Star.
Get to it.
Relax and take your time.
Let's recover what we can from this mess.
Hope for a miracle.
All right. Give me a minute--hope no one comes to check out all the shooting....
Okay. Okay. We may have something.
Chemish was getting an awful lot of messages from a terminal in the Balmorran Arms Factory. That's the Republic military base in the valley.
What does that mean?
Strange.
Does that mean Chemish was working for the Republic?
A Republic connection?
I'm not sure.
I really don't care about her personal life.
Not useful, Sanju.
These aren't personal messages. I think they're from Gray Star.
I can't believe Chemish would actually help the Republic forces--but maybe Gray Star is involved with them.
I think... if you can get to the Republic base before Gray Star learns what happened here, maybe you'll catch him.
The Gray Star's about to fall.
Let's take him out.
I'm skeptical.
Not very, frankly, but it's the only lead we've got.
You want me to break into a Republic military base?
That's suicidal.
If you have a better idea, I'd love to hear it, believe me.
I'll tell Station Chief Renald about the plan. Not like I can do any more good here.
Maybe I'll see you back in Sobrik? It's been--it's really been an honor working with you. Girl like you knows her stuff.
I know agents who could learn a thing or two from you, Sanju.
You didn't do badly, either.
Thanks. I mean that.
It's nothing special.
Of course. I know.
Learn when to keep quiet, Sanju.
Don't embarrass yourself.
Sorry. Shutting up now.
Maybe I'll see you again back in Sobrik? I hope I didn't mess up too badly.
You did fine, Sanju. We're both still alive.
Just a small mistake.
You had no way of knowing Chemish would catch on.
Not your fault.
That's enough, I guess.
Imperial Intelligence will deal with your reprimand.
You'll be punished properly.
I--yes, sir.
Good luck at the base, and good luck finding Gray Star.
Something up?
You're going to have to deal with Chemish, not me.
I'm receiving your transmission. Give me a second to fine-tune the frequency, and I'll start transferring the data.
I just talked to Station Chief Renald. He says a series of explosives went off in Sobrik--probably our power cores.
They took out a barracks and a supply depot, and they damaged one of the docks. A few dozen casualties. I just... I thought you should know.
We did what was necessary to complete the mission.
It was necessary.
No, I get that. I'll focus.
It could've been a lot worse than a few dozen casualties. We got off light.
That doesn't sound so bad.
Maybe. They probably only used half the power cores, though... doesn't matter. I'll focus.
Quit whining and focus on the job.
Don't waste my time with this.
Yes, sir. Speaking of which--huh.
You know, I think some of this outpost data came from Gray Star himself--orders, information drops, that sort of thing.
There. It's all coming in now. I guess you made it to the outpost okay?
I'm fine. What's your status?
Acknowledged.
I'm in the grasslands above the valley. Chemish didn't send anyone with me, so I can speak freely. It's actually really pretty up here.
You wouldn't believe what it took to get here.
Just barely.
Probably not. Tell me over a drink sometime.
Don't talk unless you have something useful to say.
You're babbling.
Right. Got it. Sorry.
All this data Chemish wanted us to retrieve... I think some of it's from Gray Star. Orders, communiques, all sorts of stuff.
Blast. There's a list of collaborators--Balmorrans who've been working with the Empire since the occupation. Chemish hates collaborators.
You think this is what she was after?
Oh?
I'd bet on it.
What do you think her plans are for the list?
What'll she do?
You're a collaborator yourself, aren't you?
She hates people like you.
I guess I am.
Chemish probably wants to make the list public. If the collaborators are outed, a lot of Balmorrans will want them dead.
Some of these guys are officials, factory bosses--the works. If they start getting killed, the governor's going to punish everyone.
Punish them how, exactly?
"Punish everyone"?
After a big terrorist hit, the governor rounds up a bunch of civilians. Most of them disappear forever.
If we don't give Chemish the data, she can't cause trouble. Problem solved.
So let's keep the list.
No good. She already knows the list is here. But I have an idea.
I don't care.
Look, I can send the list on to the Imperial authorities. They can set up protection for the collaborators in case Chemish goes public.
You already showed you were loyal with the Sobrik bombings. We can take a little risk here.
I know Chemish might get suspicious after what happened with the power cores, but what else can we do?
We have to maintain our cover at all costs. Even if that means people get killed.
We can't get involved.
I was afraid you'd say that. I... I won't do anything. As per your orders.
Get the message out to secure the collaborators. No one else has to die.
Let's protect whoever we can.
All right. I'll do my part. We'll hope Chemish doesn't catch on.
This isn't your call. I'm not sacrificing the mission because of your moral qualms.
You're way out of line.
I--yes. I understand that.
I need to sign off and get back to Troida. You should do the same; Sanju out.
How could you hurt his feelings? He respects you so much, and you were cruel to him! All he wanted was to save a few lives.
Now how will you two ever find happiness together? The poor boy's crushed.
I kind of feel for the stupid thing... maybe I'll have to comfort him after all.
You two are so good together. Sanju wants to save lives, you want to save lives... it's cute.
Shame you'll never find happiness together.
I don't need your opinion on him, Kaliyo.
Let it drop.
If you say so.
What can I say? People just fall at my feet.
It's not my fault men like me.
They do. Me? I have to push men down there, but it all works out.
Anyway, let's get going. No point hanging around here.
I'm really not interested in him. Let's leave it at that.
He's not my type.
Of course, this won't end well. Maybe I should have my fun with him while I have the chance.
I don't need you involving yourself with operatives. Let it go.
Leave him out of this.
Come on--I wouldn't hurt him. That would be way too easy.
Come on, Kaliyo. I'm more fun to play with.
You'd pick him instead of me?
Yeah, I'll give you that. Doesn't mean I wouldn't enjoy a little variety.
Maybe you're right, though. And I guess if he's going down, I don't need to go down with him.
You know, you say that, but I'm not convinced. Guess I have better things to do with my time, though.
The two of you can go have a ball.
Maybe you should.
Yeah. On the other hand, if he's going down, I don't really want to go down with him.
Sanju will never know what he's missed. Let's get going, huh?
Glad to see you're still alive.
Thank the stars I reached you. Sorry about earlier--with Chemish there, I couldn't say a thing.
Station Chief Renald told me you were from Imperial Intelligence, so I set things up fast as I could. Anyway, I'm Sanju Pyne. Guess you know that.
I'm Cipher Nine. Renald said good things about you.
Pleasure to meet you.
I'm trying not to mess up, anyway.
Bring me up to speed.
Do you always babble on like this?
You're rambling.
Some women think it's charming.
Sometimes. More than I'd like.
So, Chemish verified your background--Intelligence did its job. You're fine there.
I'm doing my best to find out anything about the cell leader--Gray Star. Maybe you can learn more when Chemish trusts you.
Winning over Chemish is the top priority.
That's the plan.
Right. Well, she's a fanatic, but she respects results. The more you impress her, the more she'll give.
I need you safe--finding out about Gray Star is my mission, not yours.
Don't risk yourself.
I appreciate that. But I've been inside the cell for a year now, and they haven't gotten suspicious yet.
Do you have any useful updates for me?
I know all that already.
Sorry. I just wanted to touch base.
There's one other thing: Those power cores you're after--you know what Chemish plans to do with them, right?
She's going to attack Sobrik. She'll have some of the new recruits plant the bombs and run--hit the town and the Imperial base.
Casualties? How many injured, how many dead?
Estimated damage?
What? How am I supposed to figure that? Just listen.
How horrible.
Don't interfere with this mission, Sanju.
That's part of the job.
I know, I know. Just hear me out.
I know a way to disable the power cores so Chemish won't suspect you. There's a machine in the factory that can do it.
Run the sealed case through the machine, and the cores will fry. Chemish will see you didn't unlock it--she'll assume the cores went bad over the years.
If you're wrong, the whole mission ends in failure. That's not an option.
We can't take that chance.
I know. I'll send you the machine's coordinates anyway, but... I know.
It's a risk, but we could save a lot of people. I'm in.
Let's sabotage her plan.
Great. I'll send you the machine's coordinates. We can stop a lot of bloodshed.
Enough of this.
I'm--look, I'm sorry. I was out of line, and it won't happen again. The mission is too important to risk Chemish getting suspicious.
I'll see you when you get back to Troida, okay? Sanju out.
Kind of cute, isn't he? Kind of stupid, too. If he had money, he'd be perfect.
Stay focused on the mission. We're not here to gossip.
Enough, Kaliyo.
Of course, agent.
Don't let me stand in your way.
Go for it.
I never will.
I think I'm a little offended.
Excuse me?
Just trying to be more open with you. We are partners, right?
Okay, maybe not perfect--but he might be worth a shot, anyway.
Sanju has a few things going for him.
He's not so bad.
You two would be perfect for each other. Horrifying, but true.
I say go for it. Let him enjoy a fling with a pretty spy before the terrorists shoot him dead.
If you want him, he's yours.
Go for it.
Anyone I want is mine; it's one of my charms. But I don't want Sanju.
Anyway, let's find that machine. Or maybe not.
Look, we can't talk now. Maybe later.
Don't waste my time, Sanju. You're lucky to even be here.
I got you those scramblers, didn't I? Come on, Chemish. You owe me. Maybe not big time, but you owe me.
When's the last time you did an operation for us?
What? Come on, we've been over this.
Gray Star didn't send out a call for cowards, and neither did the Eagle. Do you think--
Hey! Someone finally made it. It's great to meet you in person.
This is the group I was telling you about. I think you'll get along with them real well--better than I do, hopefully.
I've been looking forward to meeting your friends.
Good to be here.
You're cute, but I think I'd remember if we'd met.
[Flirt] Do I know you?
What are you talking about? We've never met.
I don't know you.
What? I know--sorry I had to be vague during our HoloNet talks. My real name's Sanju Pyne.
Chemish! This is the woman who got in touch with me after the Eagle's broadcast. Said she wanted to join us.
Chemish! This is the guy who got in touch with me after the Eagle's broadcast. Said he wanted to join us.
Uh-huh. Sanju says you fought the Imperials at Druckenwell. Says the Empire has a bounty on your head.
You people are the Balmorran terrorists?
You're behind the attacks?
Well, I wouldn't put it exactly like that--
You. Suppose the Empire does call us terrorists. Does that bother you?
The Empire calls a lot of good people "terrorists." I'd be proud to be one of them.
Not at all.
I like that attitude.
It's not a nice label. Carries a lot of baggage.
Should it?
True. Me, I don't really care about Imperial "labels."
The Empire calls anyone who fights back a "terrorist." But if you really kill civilians....
Only if it's true.
What we do is fight for Balmorra's freedom--however we have to. I don't worry about labels.
So. You're the one Sanju was talking about. The one with an Imperial bounty on her head. The Chiss who fought at Druckenwell.
So. You're the one Sanju was talking about. The one with an Imperial bounty on her head. The woman who fought at Druckenwell.
So. You're the one Sanju was talking about. The one with an Imperial bounty on his head. The man who fought at Druckenwell.
I didn't know you were at Druckenwell. We should talk.
Is all that real? You some ace killer looking to get the Empire off Balmorra?
I'm not saying anything until I know who I'm dealing with.
Who are you?
I'm the woman who'll shoot your head off if you're not legit.
You think I don't live up to my reputation?
You sound skeptical.
Maybe I do. Can you blame me?
I'm the Empire's worst nightmare.
That's it exactly.
Okay. Let's say that's true.
My name's Chemish. These people here--they follow Gray Star, our founder. They've been spat on, starved and punished by the Empire.
Now you--you're not from Balmorra. You haven't been through what they've been through. Makes me wonder how far I can trust you.
You don't have to trust me. Let me prove myself.
Give me a chance.
Maybe I'll do that. Maybe you can impress Gray Star.
What makes you judge and jury around here?
Why should I trust you?
See these cybernetics? Earned them after an Imperial soldier threw me to the torture droids. Because I "looked threatening." When I was eighteen.
Damn. Chemish, I never realized--
Sure, Sanju. So, yeah--I've earned respect around here. I've earned Gray Star's trust. You've got a long way to go.
I don't have time for games. If you're not going to take me seriously--
This is pointless.
Chemish--don't let it go down like this. Come on.
Fine. Gray Star isn't big on wasting resources, anyway.
Look, I don't have a problem finding people for sabotage and suicide runs.
But real soldiers? They're harder to find. So, take a job, show you're useful... then we'll talk.
You've got my attention. What's the job?
All right.
What do you mean by "take a job"?
I don't understand.
What do you want from me, Chemish?
Spit it out.
There's an abandoned factory not far from here. Used to make droids, but its defenses went haywire when the Empire took over.
Place is swarming with rogue security units. It's also full of expensive equipment. Get inside, and there's something I want.
Name it and it's yours.
Of course.
What if the place is locked down too tight?
And if I can't?
You're sending me on a salvage operation? Get serious.
This is beneath me.
If you don't think you're up for it, I can shoot you here and now--wouldn't bother me a bit.
The Okara Droid Factory produced shielded power cores for stealth droids. I want a case for my people.
My people can convert the cores into explosives, plant them around an enemy base--and thanks to the stealth shielding, no one will know until it's too late.
Sounds nasty--but sometimes nasty is what gets the job done.
I like it.
As soon as you say the word, I can be on my way.
I'll go now.
Let's be up-front: This is a test, so if you fail, don't bother coming back. We'll just kill you.
Good luck. And be careful--the factory's a nasty place.
You people have no idea what you're doing, do you?
This whole thing's a crock.
Shut up. You have a better plan? You can tell me after you prove yourself.
Just do what she asks--and don't mess up. I won't stick my neck out for you.
I don't think you're supposed to be here.
Something I can do for you?
Not sure if it's enough to actually identify him, but it's a step forward.
Anything else interesting in the computer?
What about the other data?
Might be. In fact, I bet this is what Chemish was after.
Excellent work.
The Watchers on Dromund Kaas would've solved this by now.
You're downright incompetent.
I guess. But this is Balmorra. If we had the resources Dromund Kaas has, there wouldn't be so many terrorists.
Hey--I just found something else. I bet this is what Chemish really wanted.
